alert.note: Alert for Stillwater (Montana) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Warning issued June 23 at 7:10PM MDT until June 24 at 2:00AM MDT by NWS Billings
info.description: ...FLOOD WARNING IN EFFECT UNTIL 8 AM MDT SATURDAY... * WHAT...Small stream and overland flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected to continue through early Saturday morning. * WHERE...A portion of south central Montana, including the following county, Stillwater. * WHEN...Until 800 AM MDT Saturday. * IMPACTS...Flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations is imminent or occurring. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 706 PM MDT, Doppler radar indicated heavy very heavy rain across the warned area and Law Enforcement reported flooding is already occurring in the warned area. Radar estimates between 3 and 6.5 inches of rain have fallen. Additional rain is expected overnight, but intensity should be much lighter than earlier today. - This includes the following streams and drainages... Toll Creek, Hensley Creek, Big Coulee Creek, Kenyon Creek, Dry Creek, Keyser Creek, Sixshooter Creek, Painted Robe Creek, Cummin Creek, South Fork Big Coulee Creek, South Fork Valley Creek, Cottonwood Creek, Yellowstone River, Berry Creek, North Fork Valley Creek, Greenwood Creek, Camp Creek and East White Beaver Creek. Additional rainfall amounts up to 0.5 inches are possible in the warned area. This replaces the Flash Flood Warnings for this area. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Rapelje and Hailstone Wildlife Refuge. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
info.instruction: Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Do not drive on or attempt to cross flooded roads, find an alternate route. Roads and driveways may be damaged or washed out in places. Be especially cautious at night when it is harder to recognize the dangers of flooding. Campers and hikers should avoid streams or creeks. Please report observed flooding to local emergency officials and request they pass the information to the National Weather Service in Billings.
